RoyalTitleDef.label: quirite
RoyalTitleDef.description: The title of Quirite allows one to emphasize one's status as a full citizen in the Empire. Most Imperial citizens earn it through military and volunteer service. The title can also be given to outsiders who behave in the Empire's opinion with honor and dignity.

RoyalTitleDef.label: immune
RoyalTitleDef.description: The title immune is held by those who have in some important way marked themselves as militia. While the title is not noble and does not grant more economic freedoms than a Quirite, it does give its holder the right to use low-level psi-attacks.\n\nIn the Empire, the title is often held by junior officers and other more or less significant people. Many people spend their lives as immune, seeking success in other fields.

RoyalTitleDef.label: dean
RoyalTitleDef.description:
The dean is the second rung to the imperial nobility through army titles. For the most part, they are simply immune, possessing special skills or abilities that are exempt from some tedious or dangerous work required of other militia in the service. As a rule, they also receive a higher salary than ordinary militia. Holders of this title occupy a wide range of positions in the army hierarchy - but some are just students, learning to lead troops, manage societies, or use psycasts in specialized schools. Others come from wealthy families who may have a city estate or manor.

During wartime, a dean may serve his legion as a specialist or advisor and command a small detachment of fighters.

While the immune is perceived purely as an appendage to important individuals, sending the dean to negotiate can itself be perceived as an insult.

Permit points given - 1 points.

RoyalTitleDef.label: centurion
RoyalTitleDef.description:
The title Centurion in the Empire is awarded either to members of the nobility who have successfully completed their training but have not achieved much in the way of leadership, or to outstanding deans in the army. Many centurions remain with the title forever, and outside of war represent respected stewards or advisors, and in campaigns represent a combat commander. In land battles, a Centurion leads a cohort, while in space battles he leads destroyers or battle groups.Most Centurions are quite wealthy, though there are exceptions.

 Centurion psionics are involved in espionage, sabotage and supporting fighters on the battlefield with their abilities.

Permit points given - 2 points.

RoyalTitleDef.label: tribune
RoyalTitleDef.description:
The title of tribune serves as a bridge between the army and the petty nobility, which already had some real power.

He is usually young and may belong to the most powerful families of the House or be a close friend of the legate. Nevertheless, his position was the second most senior in the legion, right after the legate. In wartime, the tribunes served as advisers and deputies to the legate.

Permit points given - 2 points.

RoyalTitleDef.label: legate
RoyalTitleDef.description:
The title of legate is almost identical to that of lord, except for two important things.

In the first place, a legate is subject to conscription and, if drafted, becomes commander of the imperial legion assigned to him. Second, a legate title is not hereditary, unlike a barony. In peacetime, legates govern the districts to which they are appointed by the planetary council.

In the Empire, the title of legatus is transitive - usually only through military service (or personal orders from higher lords) can an ordinary free citizen rise to the titles of nobility.

Permit points given - 3 points.

RoyalTitleDef.label: lord
RoyalTitleDef.description:
The title of lord is the lowest of the middle nobility. While holders of lower titles are usually engaged in military service or commerce, lords are semi-independent rulers. Each lord is subordinate to his ruler, but his obligations are mostly limited to supplying troops and finances and do not include personal service.
In the Empire, a lord typically owns a city district, a mining colony, or something similar. At wartime, a lord may formally be the captain of a large ship or lead a legion if required to do so.

Permit points given - 4 points.

RoyalTitleDef.label: viscount
RoyalTitleDef.description:
Viscount is a transitional stage between lord and count. This title was originally given to deputy of the count, but in the course of reforms in the Empire it became a full title.
In peacetime, viscount is usually a ruler of an entire city or colony, and may also have a small personal fleet, but with a limit on small ships.

Permit points given - 4 points.

RoyalTitleDef.label: count
RoyalTitleDef.description: The title of count is the middle rank of middle nobility. Counts own entire provinces and, unlike Viscounts, can have a personal fleet, including large ships.\n\nPermit points given - 5 points.

RoyalTitleDef.label: margrave
RoyalTitleDef.description: The margrave is practically the highest rung of the middle-ranking imperial nobility.\n\nIn the Empire, the margrave has the same powers as the duke, but in time of war he must fight under the duke's banner.

RoyalTitleDef.label: duke
RoyalTitleDef.description: The Imperial title of duke is the highest of the middle nobility.\n\nIn the Empire, dukes control provinces, mega-cities, or moons. At war, a duke can field a division-level force, or a fleet with capital ships and dozens of support craft.

RoyalTitleDef.label: archduke
RoyalTitleDef.description: The title of Archduke is the lowest level of the Imperial highest nobility.\n\nIn the Empire, Archduchess command entire regions of planets, controlling the lands entrusted to them by the head of the House. In wartime, the Archduke can lead an entire army consisting of several divisions, supported by several space fleets. Some command from a super-capital ship or control space-based megastructures.

RoyalTitleDef.label: head of the Minor House
RoyalTitleDef.description: The title of head of a Minor House is practically a dream for any imperial nobleman.\n\nThe heads of a Minor House rule parts of planets or important organizations throughout the Empire. Their power is limited only to the Great Houses and the Padishah-Emperor himself. Despite the seemingly enormous possibilities, such a title is extremely dangerous - many heads of Houses do not die of natural causes.

RoyalTitleDef.label: head of the Great House
RoyalTitleDef.description: In the Empire, due to navigational problems and the cost of interstellar travel, the heads of the Great Houses rule their systems with a high degree of independence. Each swears allegiance to the Padishah-Emperor, but because the Emperor can be many light years away, the heads of the Great Houses often do not contact him directly for years.

RoyalTitleDef.label: Padishah-Emperor
RoyalTitleDef.description: The Imperial title of Padishah-Emperor indicates sovereign dominion over the entire Empire, all its peoples, planets, and fleets. All other lords swear fealty to a high lord, while the Emperor swears fealty to no one. However, even he depends on the support of lower nobles to remain in power.
